meta.title: Coronavirus and Cold/Flu Season Information - Lodi Unified School District

meta.name: description
meta.content: Coronavirus and Cold/Flu Season Information - Lodi Unified School District

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: Coronavirus and Cold/Flu Season Information, Lodi Unified School District
Coronavirus and Cold/Flu Season Information - Lodi Unified School District
Coronavirus and Cold/Flu Season Information - Lodi Unified School District

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasMenu fsHasFooter fsHasTwoColumnLayout fsSection321 fsHasTheme2

li.a: April 2, 2020 - Video Update from Superintendent Nichols-Washer
March 31, 2020 - Prior Written Notice Regarding Special Education Services
March 30, 2020 - Video Update from Superintendent Nichols-Washer
March 18, 2020 - Special Message from Superintendent Nichols-Washer

div.p: To Lodi USD Parents/Guardians,

We greatly miss seeing our students and spending time with them in the regular school environment. We know this has been very challenging and we appreciate the support you provide everyday. This letter provides important information about our Distance Learning Plan. The entire document can be found on the district website. The plan is designed around a “hold harmless” framework so that no student’s academic record will be harmed due to this situation. We hope you will take advantage of all the learning opportunities from teachers as well as utilize additional resources such as those that can be found on our website. School buildings and offices are not open to the public for the remainder of the school year. If you have questions or need assistance, please call the school or use the Contact Us section on the school website.

p.b: If you do not have internet at home, please contact your school as soon as possible or call (209) 331-7010.

div.p: Schools will notify 12th graders of dates to return equipment and books.
Schools will notify 9-11th graders when to return books. They bring Chromebooks when school reopens.
Schools will notify 7th and 8th graders of dates to exchange technology equipment (before the end of May).
K-6 grade students will keep their current equipment and bring it when school reopens.

ul.li: All high schools will hold an alternative graduation celebration by the end of the school year. Details are determined by each school site.

All high schools are making plans to host an in person graduation if permitted by health/safety requirements/guidelines to be held by August 7, 2020. The decision to have this ceremony will be made by June 30, 2020.
Middle schools will plan 8th grade promotion recognitions in alignment with health/safety requirements/guidelines. Details are determined by each school site.

li.p: All other student recognition activities will be determined by the school sites.

ul.li: Meals for students are available at designated locations on Mondays and Wednesdays. Locations and times can be found on the district website.

div.p: We greatly appreciate your patience and cooperation as we work on this important effort. We are committed to providing essential services to our students and community.
Wishing you health and safety,
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Ed. D.
Lodi Unified School District Distance Learning

ul.li: 1-2 hours a day (10 hours per week) and physical activity.
Students will not receive a lesser grade than their grade on March 13, 2020.
Teachers will share student progress with parents.
2-3 hours a day (15 hours per week for all courses combined)

li.p: Students will receive Pass/Fail grades on progress reports to be distributed in the mail during the first week of May.

For the final grade, students will receive a Pass/Fail grade based on the grade they had prior to March 13, 2020. However, if a student had a Fail at that time, the student may make progress to earn a Pass as the final grade.
Grades earned after March 13, 2020, will not be used in the calculation for promotion ceremonies or recognitions and all 8th grade students will move on to 9th grade.

ul.li: 15-18 hours per week for all courses combined.
Students will not receive a lesser grade than their grade on March 13, 2020.
Students will be able to earn a higher grade.
Students will have the choice of taking their letter grade or Credit/No Credit.
For classes starting after March 6, students will earn a grade and can select Credit/No Credit.
Semester grades will be posted in Aeries by May 22 at 2:30 P.M.
Students can view tentative final grades to help decide if they want to request Credit in lieu of grades.
Students have until May 28, 2020 at 2:30 P.M. to request Credit/No Credit on the Credit Petition Form.
Students submit a Credit Petition Form to each teacher for each request (details available soon).
Students with an F will automatically be assigned No Credit.
Students may be assigned credit recovery as an option to make up credits.

div.p: Lodi USD High School Seniors and Parents/Guardians of Seniors,

Lodi USD understands that this is supposed to be an exciting time in your educational career full of activities, events, and ceremonies to celebrate your accomplishments and future endeavors. You deserve to be recognized and honored.
We want to make sure that we have plans in place to celebrate you even in this unprecedented environment that is beyond anyone’s control.

The District now has a framework for high school graduations that was developed with input from students, parents, teachers, and other staff. The framework includes two parts with the goals of recognizing seniors before the end of the school year and leaving the opportunity open for an in-person live ceremony if health guidelines permit.

ul.li: Each high school will plan and hold an alternate and/or virtual recognition before May 30, 2020. Each school will communicate the details of their process to you as they become available.

Each high school will plan for and be ready to host a live/in-person graduation ceremony to take place sometime between May 30 and August 7, 2020. The decision to move forward with this ceremony will be decided by June 30 and will be based on the health/safety requirements and guidelines that are in place during that time. While the ceremony may not be the same as in the past, we want to preserve the opportunity to hold this important celebration to the extent possible.

div.p: Example: Health and safety requirements change on June 1 that would allow for an in-person ceremony. High schools can then schedule their ceremony for any day up to August 7.
We know that our schools will do everything possible to make this important rite of passage the best it can be.
Thank you for your continued support and understanding.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

ul.li: Distance Learning Plan - English
Distance Learning Plan - Spanish

div.p: Lodi USD greatly appreciates your feedback regarding remote learning. We understand that this may have caused frustration as you have been waiting for more information about long-term plans.

Based on recommendations from our Distance Learning Task Force, which represented teachers, counselors, registrars, and administrators, the District’s required distance learning effort will begin the week of April 13, 2020.
Students will receive instruction through remote venues focused on standards-aligned instruction with the intent of moving learning forward.

The District is working with state officials and internet providers to address internet access issues. We understand that this may take a little time, but it is a state-wide priority. Parents can communicate needs in this area to their child’s teacher or principal.

The attached document provides more information about the District’s direction on distance learning, including grading. Please look for communications from your teacher(s) next week on specifics related to their classes.

Our teachers and support staff have been doing a phenomenal job with remote learning. As I’m sure you have seen, there have been many examples of creative and engaging lessons. This direction represents the continuation and enhancement of these efforts.
Thank you for your continued patience and support.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

h2.a: April 2, 2020 - Video Update from Superintendent Nichols-Washer

ul.li: Closed Captions - English
Closed Captions - Spanish

video.div: Your web browser does not support the <video> tag.

div.p: Based on the recommendation from our County Superintendent of Schools and information from the State Superintendent of Schools and Governor, our District will remain closed through the end of the 2019-20 school year.
The health of our students, staff and community are of the utmost importance and it is vital that we ensure we are all doing our part to help stop the spread of COVID-19.
We know this is upsetting and we share your disappointment that we will not be able to end this school year as planned.

Our community relies on our schools to educate our children. Even though schools are closed, we will continue to provide education through remote learning. Our teachers and staff have done a tremendous job navigating this unprecedented time, and we are committed to continuing to support our students.
As the California Department of Education provides more guidance on this situation, our District will continue to develop remote teaching and learning activities for the rest of the school year.
We know there are still questions from staff and families. We will provide more details as they become available.
We appreciate the continued support and understanding from our families.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

ul.li: 504 Prior Written Notice - English
Parent Procedural Safeguards - English
504 Prior Written Notice - Spanish
Parent Procedural Safeguards -Spanish

h2.a: March 31, 2020 - Prior Written Notice Regarding Special Education Services

ul.li: Prior Written Notice regarding Special Education Services during School Closure - English
Prior Written Notice regarding Special Education Services during School Closure - Spanish

h2.a: March 30, 2020 - Video Update from Superintendent Nichols-Washer

ul.li: Closed Captions - English
Closed Captions - Spanish

video.div: Your web browser does not support the <video> tag.

div.p: Our teachers have been hard at work preparing lessons and remote learning opportunities for our students. Teachers will share this with their students beginning March 31. At this time, remote learning is optional for students but we encourage our families to take advantage of these learning opportunities.
We are excited to see our teachers’ creative approaches to remote learning. If you’d like to share how your child is learning, please tag us and use #LodiLearns and #LodiLearnsFromHome.

This week, the San Joaquin County Office of Education recommended extending all school closures through Friday April 17, 2020. Our District extended our closure through this date to protect the health of our students and staff members, and to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

We understand that this timeline could be extended based on the status of this health crisis. We want you to know that we hear you and we are working on issues related to distance learning, such as grades, credits, high school classes that have just started, support for students with special needs, and preparing students for the next school year.
We will provide you with additional information regarding these issues as soon as possible. Thank you for your continued patience and support.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

p.span: Lodi at significant risk of expanding COVID-19 cases
City Council, health leaders ask community to boost efforts to fight virus

div.p: Members of the Lodi City Council and leaders of Adventist Health Lodi Memorial and Lodi Unified School District are imploring the community to follow the stay-at-home orders issued by the Governor and San Joaquin County, saying Friday that Lodi is now at significant risk for an increase of COVID-19 activity.

Councilman and physician Alan Nakanishi said he has never been more concerned about the wellbeing of the Lodi community than he is now, pointing to the explosive viral outbreaks in New York City, Seattle and New Orleans as indications of what could happen here.
“I know the stay-at-home orders are an inconvenience and we want our lives to return to normal,” Nakanishi said. “But this virus can affect everyone, regardless of age. Please take this seriously.”

Daniel Wolcott, president of Adventist Health Lodi Memorial, said the hospital’s predictions and current caseload make it clear that the hospital will not have enough beds to serve the expected surge of patients if we do not bend the curve of this infection. He said everyone needs to adhere to recommendations for social distancing, hygiene and frequent surface cleaning. Those steps are imperative to help slow the disease’s spread, which will allow medical professional to serve those with other health needs.

“If you think this is just about the elderly, you are wrong,” Wolcott said. “It’s about anyone who needs hospital care during the surge. Our healthcare workers want to be able to deliver the best care to every patient with every need— whether it is labor and delivery, stroke care, auto injury or chest pain. We don’t want to have to choose which types of patients get care. Please stay home!”

Wolcott added that hospital staff is now seeing new COVID-19 patients who have disregarded the warnings, including those who sought care directly after leaving their workplaces and local shopping centers.
The warnings are not for a specific group of people. The hospital is treating COVID-19-positive patients of all ages and demographics.

“There are plenty of stories about young people not taking this health threat seriously,” Wolcott said. “But, unfortunately, many members of the most at-risk populations, such as the elderly, are also disregarding and downplaying the warnings.”
Lodi Unified School District Superintendent Cathy Nichols-Washer said that although schools are scheduled to reopen on April 20, “this timeline could be extended based on the health crisis.”

San Joaquin County on Thursday tightened its stay-at-home order to ban gatherings of any size, in public or private areas, outside of immediate household members. It eliminated the April 7 expiration date in previous orders, making the new order in effect until rescinded, among other changes.
Lodi Mayor Doug Kuehne and Wolcott said the county needed to strengthen the order now in order to decrease the spread of COVID-19.

“Unfortunately, not all are taking this health threat seriously,” Kuehne said. “Not only are people needlessly risking their health, they’re risking the lives of their families, coworkers and friends, and it needs to stop.”
For more information about COVID-19, visit www.sjready.org, www.adventisthealthlodimemorial.org, www.cdc.gov/coronavirus, or www.cdph.ca.gov.
Beginning Monday, March 30, Lodi USD will add a new drive thru stop and school bus service locations for meal service.

ul.li: Children must be present in order for meals to be provided.
Meals will be provided based on the number of children present.
These meals will be available free of charge for anyone 18 and under regardless of their school of residence.
No paperwork is required.

div.p: The meals will be offered for pickup only, and meals will not be consumed on-site. We encourage families to continue to be proactive in reducing the risk of COVID-19 by utilizing social distancing once meals have been distributed.
Sites and serving times are subject to change, so please refer to our website. You can also text the word “FOOD” to 877-877 to find the closest locations.

ul.li: Closed captions - English
Closed captions - Spanish

div.p: To protect the health of our students and staff members, and to help slow the spread of COVID-19, James Mousalimas, San Joaquin County Superintendent of Schools, recommended extending all school closures through Friday April 17, 2020.
At this time, Lodi USD schools will remain closed through April 17, 2020.

As this is a rapidly changing situation, the District will continue to provide any updated schedule information as it becomes available. Our District continues to communicate with SJCOE and local and state health officials. We understand that this timeline could be extended based on the status of this health crisis.

This week, our teachers are planning and preparing remote learning activities and resources for our students. This will be provided to families beginning Tuesday, March 31. In the meantime, families can access our remote resources at this link.
We are working on a Chromebook pick up process and schools will send communication to families soon.
We will continue to provide you with updates as quickly as possible. We are updating our FAQ document as well.
Thank you for your continued support and patience while we navigate through this pandemic.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

br.br:
Late last night, a Lodi USD District Office employee self-reported being positive for COVID-19. Although not confirmed by Public Health, out of an abundance of caution, we closed the District Office. Our custodial crew responded quickly and sanitization started early this morning.
The staff member has not been in the building for several days. We know you may want more information but please understand that federal health privacy laws prohibit us from releasing more information about this employee.
Meal service is not impacted and will continue as scheduled. Our Nutrition Services staff will continue to use the highest standards for food preparation and safety.
We understand this is a stressful situation for everyone. We are vigilant about working with local and state public health officials to investigate all reported or suspected cases of COVID-19. If at any time you have a fever, cough, and shortness of breath, public health officials request that you please reach out to your primary care provider for further guidance.
We are informed by PHS that there is community spread of COVID-19. As testing is increasing, public health officials expect to see more results that are positive for COVID-19. This is why we, as a school district, have closed schools and why the State of California has issued the stay at home orders.
As a reminder, the following are guidelines to help slow down the spread of the virus:
-continue to practice social distancing
-wash your hands with soap and water frequently – even while at home
-cover your coughs and sneezes
-clean commonly touched surfaces with wipes
-report any fever, cough, shortness of breath to your primary care provider and request to be tested.
-For additional information, please refer to our website: http://bit.ly/39riLF4.

div.p: Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

Last night, the Governor issued a Stay at Home Order effective throughout the State of California. The order does not change the role of schools. The Governor’s previous direction to schools remains. To learn more about this order, please visit the State’s COVID-19 website.
We know this brings a heightened level of concern but we want to assure you that we will continue to provide critical services to our students, including the scheduled meal service starting Monday.
We know you are anxious for more information as our school closure begins Monday.

Next week, teachers will prepare resources and activities to be ready for students starting on Monday, March 31. In the meantime, parents can use resources and activities we are adding on our website. Information about Chromebook pick up will be provided early next week.
Beginning Monday, March 23, students can receive daily meals in a drive thru or walk up meal service.

ul.li: Children must be present in order for meals to be provided.
Meals will be provided based on the number of children present.
These meals will be available free of charge for anyone 18 and under regardless of what school they attend.
No paperwork is required.

div.p: The meals will be offered for pickup only, and meals will not be consumed on-site. We encourage families to continue to be proactive in reducing the risk of COVID-19 by utilizing social distancing once meals have been distributed.
A list of the meal service sites can be found on our website. You can also text the word “FOOD” to 877-877 to find the closest locations.
Starting Monday, March 23, 2020, all District offices, buildings, and facilities will be closed to the public to help mitigate the impact of COVID- 19. Phone appointments will be available.

These closures will remain in effect until Friday, April 3, 2020, with the exception of a Special Board Meeting on March 24, 2020 at 6PM at the JAESC. At this time, schools will resume on Monday, April 6, 2020. All District offices, buildings, and facilities will reopen to the public on that date, unless otherwise stated.

We know there will continue to be questions and we will continue to address them as best as we can. We are disappointed that we won’t see our students on Monday but we will make every effort to provide quality resources that can be done at home to enhance learning.
Thank you for your continued support.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

p.span: City of Lodi, Adventist Health Lodi Memorial, Lodi Unified and Lodi Chamber urge community members to follow COVID-19 guidance

div.p: Although many Lodi residents, businesses and other groups are following public health officials’ guidance to reduce the spread of the coronavirus, COVID-19, others need to intensify their efforts, local leaders said today.

Lodi Mayor Doug Kuehne, Adventist Health Lodi Memorial President Daniel Wolcott, Lodi Unified Superintendent Cathy Nichols-Washer and Lodi Chamber of Commerce President Pat Patrick urge all of Lodi to comply with recommendations to maintain social distancing of remaining at least six feet from others, as well as refrain from gathering in groups of 10 or more people. Detailed guidance for individuals, businesses and organizations is available from the California Department of Public Health Services (CDPH).

“Each of us need to do our part, as a community and as a nation, to prevent the spread of COVID-19,” Kuehne said. “We’re in the early stages of this outbreak. Following the measures recommended by health leaders at the federal, state and local levels will allow us to protect the health of countless Americans.”
President Trump on Monday asked that Americans stay at home except for essential travel for the next 15 days, and to comply with guidelines issued by state and local authorities.

City Manager Steve Schwabauer proclaimed a local health emergency on Monday in response to the pandemic, which the City Council is scheduled to ratify on Wednesday. The proclamation allows the City to request State and federal funds designated for local health efforts.
The four community leaders today urged businesses to find creative ways of serving their customers at a distance, such as curbside pick-up and delivery and to encourage employees to work from home when possible, in accordance with CDPH guidelines. They also encouraged residents to patronize those businesses that are following the recommendations.

“These are extraordinary times and we know the guidelines create a hardship for many,” Patrick said. “But these are the steps we must follow so we can emerge from this threat sooner than later.”
Today’s joint statement is not intended to cause panic in the community, but to serve as a reminder that although most people can recover from a coronavirus infection, the elderly and those with underlying health conditions are especially vulnerable.
COVID-19 can be spread by persons who are unaware they are infected, and the virus can remain viable for days at a time depending on the surface, making it particularly difficult to stop.

San Joaquin County Public Health Services on Wednesday reported the county’s first two deaths from COVID-19 complications.
While Adventist Health Lodi Memorial is prepared to treat patients with COVID-19, beds and equipment are limited. Preventing or slowing the virus’ spread will allow the hospital to better serve those needing intense treatment, Wolcott said.

“It is critically important that we all think differently about this crisis,” Wolcott said. “We must heed the counsel of our public health leaders and take precautions seriously. We must encourage those we know to self-isolate and curtail any activity that puts others in connection with anyone who may be infected.”

h2.a: March 18, 2020 - Special Message from Superintendent Nichols-Washer

div.p: I want to thank our families and staff for your patience as we work through this challenging national pandemic situation. We understand that the Governor has given his opinion regarding the possibility of schools remaining closed through the end of the school year. I have to admit that this was very disheartening. As an educator, I value public education and know firsthand how hard staff work to provide quality instruction in a safe environment. As a parent, I remember the joy I felt driving a car full of young ladies to the mall to get prom dresses and hosting a couple dozen teenagers for their prom dinner. It is sad to think that the youth in our community may not experience some of the wondrous events associated with growing up.

I know that many of you are frustrated and angered by school closures and the unknown future, but we all also acknowledge that we must take this situation seriously and do all that we can to support the children we serve.

Lodi USD is working on methods to provide remote learning and we have a daily student meal program set up. More information about both will be provided in separate communications. Please understand that many employees will be working remotely and information or products that were available to the public quickly may be delayed. We also are aware that not all students have their district Chromebooks at home. We are working on a plan to get those out.

At this time, Lodi USD is on its regular break and is currently scheduled to resume on April 6, 2020. Please understand that this is a fluid situation and that direction can change unexpectedly, especially in light of recent media releases by government officials. We fully understand the impact this situation has on our staff and families and we will do our very best to provide quality service to both.
Thank you for your continued support and patience.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent
Beginning on Monday, March 23, 2020 you can pick up two meals daily (lunch and breakfast for the following day) in a drive thru or walk up meal service.

ul.li: Children must be present in order for meals to be provided.
Meals will be provided based on the number of children present.
These meals will be available free of charge for anyone 18 and under regardless of what school they attend.
No paperwork is required.

div.p: The meals will be offered for pickup only, and meals will not be consumed on-site. We encourage families to continue to be proactive in reducing the risk of COVID-19 by utilizing social distancing once meals have been distributed.
Sites and serving times are subject to change, so please refer to our website. You can also text the word “FOOD” to 877-877 to find the closest locations.

This afternoon, all Superintendents in San Joaquin County school districts, in consultation with San Joaquin County Public Health Services, determined that it is in the best interest of our communities to close schools to help mitigate the impact of the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). As we are currently on break, Lodi Unified School District will postpone the reopening of school until Monday, April 6, 2020. All student activities and programs are cancelled during this time that school is not in session. We are not closing down the District.
We know this will raise many questions. We will provide additional information next week and we will continue to update our website.
Once again, school will resume on April 6.
Thank you for your continued patience and support.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

Lodi Unified School District is closely monitoring information and guidance from the California Department of Public Health (CDPH), San Joaquin County Public Health Services (PHS), and San Joaquin County Office of Education (SJCOE) regarding the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). We continue to converse with these agencies about new developments and the impact on schools.
As you know, this is a quickly changing situation and we will provide information and updates to our community as soon as possible.

On March 11, 2020, CDPH announced new guidelines to slow the transmission rate of COVID-19. CDPH recommends that the following events should be postponed or canceled across the State of California for at least the remainder of March, 2020.

ul.li: Large gatherings that include 250 people or more
Smaller gatherings that do not allow for social distancing of six feet per person
Gathering of individuals who are at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19 should be limited to no more than 10 people

div.p: CDPH advises that these recommendations apply to all non-essential professional, social, and community gatherings. A “gathering” is any event that brings people together in a single room or space at the same time, such as an auditorium, stadium, arena, large conference room, meeting hall, cafeteria or any other indoor or outdoor space. This guidance does not apply to activities such as attendance at regular school classes, work, or essential services.
The above guidelines do not apply to the following essential school functions:
For Students

ul.li: Classes
Passing periods/recess
Lunches
District After School Program

div.p: For Employees

ul.li: All contracted responsibilities

div.p: The above guidelines do apply to all other school activities including Interscholastic Sports.

The California Interscholastic Federation (CIF) has canceled all remaining CIF State Basketball Championship games. This includes regional finals scheduled for March 12, 2020, and the CIF State finals scheduled for March 13-14, 2020, at Golden 1 Center in Sacramento.
The Science Olympiad event scheduled for Saturday, March 14, 2020, at McNair High School is canceled.

There are three confirmed cases of COVID-19 in San Joaquin County. On March 12, 2020, PHS declared a Local Public Health Emergency. This will assist in leveraging additional resources and funding in response to the COVID-19 outbreak.

Per PHS, this should not be reason for heightened concern. The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and Prevention reports that for the general public, the immediate health risk from COVID-19 is low. Currently, there are no confirmed cases within the Lodi USD population of students and staff.

p.strong: Per current guidance from public health officials, schools in San Joaquin County are not closing. Lodi USD will resume classes on March 23, 2020.

div.p: Lodi USD is closely monitoring the travel advisories and is currently restricting school sponsored travel to contagion areas for both students and staff.

Please review the map on the CDPH website, which shows the areas that have confirmed cases of COVID-19. Travel within a Level 2 Travel Health Notice or higher will be restricted (please see CDC website for descriptions of Levels).

Per CDC, families that have traveled to a country with a Level 3 Health Notice will be asked to stay home for 14 days. If you have traveled to one of the identified areas, please inform your school site.

We understand that our community is very concerned about this situation and Lodi USD takes this seriously. During this break, we are thoroughly cleaning all schools. School site custodians are using a new spray method of disinfecting large areas such as classrooms, restrooms, cafeterias, and buses. This is proving to be a very effective method of sanitization and we thank our Maintenance and Operations staff for an outstanding job. In addition, custodians continue to focus on cleaning high-touch items throughout the schools.

The District has purchased alcohol-based hand sanitizer so that hand sanitization is possible if soap and water are not readily accessible, per CDC recommendation. We expect the product to arrive by the time school resumes.

We know there are still questions and concerns and we will continue to share information about District procedures. We are also aware that this situation can change rapidly causing school districts to modify responses. We will keep our community informed of any new information and/or changes. Please see the Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) document on our website for further information.
As a reminder, please continue to practice good hygiene to help prevent the spread of any virus including hand washing, avoid touching your eyes/nose/mouth, and covering cough/sneeze with a tissue.
We appreciate all of the hard work the Lodi USD staff members have done to address this health issue.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

San Joaquin County Public Health Services (PHS) informed us today of the first laboratory-confirmed case of the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in San Joaquin County. According to PHS, this individual was a passenger on the Grand Princess cruise ship; however, they were not on the cruise that is currently disembarking in Oakland.

As COVID-19 concerns continue to be a priority, we want to keep you updated on our plans for keeping our schools, students and staff safe. Lodi USD is working closely with public health officials and the San Joaquin County Office of Education (SJCOE), and we will continue to provide our community with new information as it becomes available.

While the progression of COVID-19 is still evolving, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and Prevention reports that for the general public, the immediate health risk from COVID-19 is considered low.

We have implemented additional sanitation procedures to our daily routines. The District is thoroughly cleaning facilities with a new spray method of disinfecting large areas such as classrooms, restrooms, cafeterias, and buses. After this initial cleaning, the spray method will continue to be implemented. In addition, all custodians continue to focus on cleaning high-touch items, such as tables, chairs, doorknobs, light switches, desks, restroom fixtures, drinking fountains.
Public health officials continue to remind us that the most important way to prevent the spread of germs is for all of us to be diligent with our own hygiene practices:

ul.li: Stay home until you are fever free for 24 hours without fever reducing medication.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water is not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
Individuals with chronic health issues and/or individuals experiencing severe symptoms should be evaluated by a medical professional.
Think about how to care for loved ones at home if they or you get sick, including how to prevent other family members from becoming infected.

div.p: This is a rapidly-changing situation but please know that health and safety is of the utmost importance, and we will keep our community informed. We will continue to update our website and our FAQ document as new information becomes available.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent
We are committed to keeping you informed about our response to the national and global public health situation involving the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).
As of March 6, 2020 there are no known cases of COVID-19 in our County.
We hope everyone has a restful spring break over the next two weeks. We want to remind you to take all preventative measures to protect yourself and our community from COVID-19 and other illnesses.

It is important to know that anyone who travels outside of the country will be screened upon re-entry to the United States, pursuant to the requirements of state and federal officials. According to CDC, if you travel to a country with a Level 3 Travel Health Notice, you will be asked to stay home for a period of 14 days from the time you left an area with widespread or ongoing community spread. For more information on CDC travel alerts, please visit their website. If you travel to one of these countries, please inform your school site.

The health and safety of our students and staff remain our utmost priority. We will continue to monitor guidance from local and state health officials regarding COVID-19. We will send you information and update our website.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent
We have placed a Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) document on our website regarding the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). We will continue to update this document and keep our community informed.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

We have been informed by San Joaquin Delta College that one of their health science students who works at a medical facility outside of the County was exposed to the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).
According to Delta College, the student is showing no symptoms of the virus and is now in 14-day self-isolation, per guidance from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and Prevention. The exposure happened while the student was treating a patient at the medical facility on Sunday. The patient had not tested positive for COVID-19 at that time. The health sciences student was on the Delta College campus on Monday before it was known that the student had been exposed.
We understand that this is concerning but we want to reassure you that this is an exposure only. There are still NO confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the County.
At this time, Delta College is working closely with public health experts; there are no plans to close their campus or cancel classes. Middle College High School classes will continue as normal.
The District will continue to monitor information from CDC, California Department of Public Health, San Joaquin County Public Health Services, and San Joaquin County Office of Education.
This is a rapidly-changing situation but please know that health and safety is of the utmost importance and we will keep our community informed.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

We understand that there is increased concern regarding the Novel Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19). Lodi Unified continues to monitor information from the Center for Disease Control (CDC) and Prevention, San Joaquin County Public Health (SJCPH), and San Joaquin County Office of Education (SJCOE). At this time, there are no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in San Joaquin County.

According to the CDC, most people get infected with viruses in the coronavirus family at some point in their lives. The 2019 novel strain at the center of the current issue is a new one and can have a more severe impact in terms of respiratory illness with fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. The CDC is still studying how the virus spreads, though it is thought at this point to be spread much like other respiratory illnesses.

In an effort to enhance our health/safety procedures, based on recommendations from health authorities, the District is in the process of purchasing alcohol-based hand sanitizer so that hand sanitization is possible if soap and water are not readily accessible.
Other recommended preventative measures include:

ul.li: Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough.
Sneeze into a tissue then throw the tissue away in the trash. Wash your hands afterward.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
Get a flu shot.

div.p: If your child has any of the following symptoms, please make sure to keep them home:

ul.li: Signs of a fever
Cough
Difficulty breathing
Shortness of breath

div.p: Remember to call your school and notify them of the illness. If staff notice that your child exhibits flu-like symptoms, the school will contact you to pick up your child.
This is a rapidly-changing situation but please know that health and safety is of the utmost importance and we will keep our community informed.
Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent

Lodi USD is closely monitoring the Novel Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19), first identified in December in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. We have been following all guidance from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and the California Department of Public Health (CDPH). We are also working closely with San Joaquin County Public Health (SJCPH) to ensure student and staff safety.

Per CDPH, as of February 28, 2020, there are a total of 34 positive cases in California: 24 are from repatriation flights. The other ten confirmed cases include seven that are travel related, one due to person-to-person exposure from a very close contact (a spouse) and two from unknown sources. These numbers align with the CDC. Approximately 200 persons have been tested to date.
For more information on the travel advisory issued by the U.S. Department of State, please see the China Travel Advisory - January 30, 2020.

On February 25, 2020, CDC urged schools to prepare for possible COVID-19 outbreaks in the United States. While the CDC’s comments have generated a lot of concern, it is important to note there is still a very low health risk to the general public in California. In addition, schools are well prepared for a potential outbreak, having experience preventing regular illnesses such as the flu and common cold.

It is important to take steps to be prepared but we want to reassure our community that the current threat to our County is low and there is no cause for panic. Our schools are currently using disinfects, such as Clorox and hand sanitizer. In addition, our custodial staff use specialized equipment when applying disinfectants in order to achieve the best coverage possible.
We encourage our students and staff to practice everyday prevention, including:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough.
Sneeze into a tissue then throw the tissue away in the trash. Wash your hands afterward.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
Get a flu shot.

div.p: Cathy Nichols-Washer, Superintendent
